For e.g. I suspect the widespread adoption of ADAS (and possibly connected vehicle technology) will reduce the complexity of the driving ecosystem by lessening the input of humans.

The fewer human inputs, the fewer edge cases, and thus easier to solve the response time problem.

Among other problems, AAA automotive researchers found that vehicles with active driving assistance systems (ADAS) often disengage with little notice ‚Äî almost instantly handing control back to the driver.

Automated Lane Keeping Assist Systems (ALKS) are not Automated Driving.

The UK Government is preparing for Automated Driving by Spring 2021. We support the development of this tech but ALKS only meets 2 of our criteria for safe Automated Driving, therefore it's Assisted Driving

WATCH: What happens if you're driving a car with Automated Lane Keeping Assist Systems and there's debris on the road üò¨‚ö†Ô∏è

ALKS-enabled systems can't change lanes if there's debris or even a pedestrian on the road.

This is why we believe ALKS is Assisted Driving, not Automated.
